1.statement: This outcome does not prove that Denosumab is effective because there is no comparison group.

   • A single cohort of 33 patients all received one dose of denosumab.

   • No information is given about any placebo group, active-control group, or historical comparator included in the same study design.

2. What the statement claims  
   “This outcome does not prove that Denosumab is effective because there is no comparison group.”

3. Evaluating the claim with medical research principles  
   • In clinical research, proof of efficacy generally requires comparison with a control group to rule out spontaneous improvement, measurement bias, or other confounders.  
   • A single-arm response rate can suggest activity but cannot, by itself, prove causality or establish efficacy to the standard required for evidence-based conclusions.

4. Applying that principle to the premise  
   • Because the study only reports outcomes in patients who all received denosumab and lacks any comparator, the observed 63.6 % response cannot conclusively attribute the effect to the drug.  
   • Therefore, the statement accurately characterizes the limitation of the presented result.

Conclusion  
The statement is factually correct.
